Problem:
Consider a complex function mapping defined by \( z(t) = e^{i \omega t} z_0 \), where \( \omega \) is a real constant and \( z_0 \) is a complex number. We analyze the impact of applying a Fourier transform to \( z(t) \), represented by \( \mathcal{F}\{z(t)\}(s) \).

If an additional Fourier operative, represented by a filtering process \( h(s) \), is applied to transform \( \mathcal{F}\{z(t)\}(s) \), will the resulting output be fundamentally dependent only on \( \omega \) and not the initial condition \( z_0 \)?
Explanation: The intervention with a filter \( h(s) \) adds another layer of transformation, making the filtered output dependent not just on \( \omega \), but also significantly on \( z_0 \). The initial conditions and the specific nature of the filter would influence the resultant spectral composition.
